{{Infobox Organization |name= Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association |image_border= IGSSALogo.png |size=120px |headquarters=[[North Ryde, New South Wales|North Ryde]], [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]] {{flagicon|Australia}} |membership=29 member schools |language= [[English language|English]] |general= Ms Vicki Steer ([[Ravenswood School for Girls|Ravenswood]])<ref name=IGSSACommittee>{{cite web |url=http://igssa.ahigs.nsw.edu.au/DeskTopDefault.aspx?tabid=291 |title=Standing Committee |accessdate=2009-03-27 |work=Member Schools |publisher=Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association}}</ref> |formation= 1922<ref name=IGSSAintro/> |website= [http://igssa.ahigs.nsw.edu.au/ igssa.ahigs.nsw.edu.au] }}
The '''Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association''' (commonly known as '''IGSSA'''), was established in [[Sydney, New South Wales|Sydney]], [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]], in 1922 with five founding members,<ref name=PLCSport>{{cite web |url = http://www.plc.nsw.edu.au/public2/index.html|title = Specialities - Sport |accessdate = 2007-09-14 |work=Cocurricular |publisher = Presbyterian Ladies' College, Sydney |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070818122348/http://www.plc.nsw.edu.au/public2/index.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-08-18}}</ref> all of them [[Independent school|independent]] Protestant girls' schools.
Today, the 29 member schools of the [[Association of Heads of Independent Girls' Schools]] (AHIGS), both [[Catholic school|Catholic]] and independent schools, compete against each other in a number of [[sport]]ing carnivals and termly sports through the association. [[Secondary school]] girls compete in team and individual sports at school level and can be selected through IGSSA for state representative teams and higher competitions.<ref name=IGSSAintro>{{cite web |url=http://igssa.ahigs.nsw.edu.au/DeskTopDefault.aspx?tabid=1 |title=Welome to IGSSA |accessdate=2007-09-14 |work=Introduction |publisher=Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association}}</ref>
==History== The Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association was established in 1922<ref name=PLCSport/> as the Girls Secondary Schools Sports Union.<ref name=Tildesley/> Commencing with just five members,<ref name=PLCSport/> all of them independent, [[Protestant]] schools for girls,<ref name=Tildesley/> IGSSA grew rapidly in the 1980s and 90s following the introduction of graded competition for many sports, improving competitions and adding new sports.<ref name=IGSSAintro/>
Today IGSSA (or the AHIGS Sporting Committee) is a sub–committee of the [[Association of Heads of Independent Girls' Schools]] (AHIGS).<ref name=IGSSAintro/>

== Sports == The AHIGS Sporting Committee (IGSSA) organises competitions among 29 independent girls' schools in New South Wales. Secondary school girls compete in team and individual sports at school level and may be selected through IGSSA for state teams and other higher competitions. IGSSA works with each member school's [[physical education]] and sport programme by providing interschool competition from beginners to elite level.<ref name=IGSSAintro/>
IGSSA graded competitions are held on Saturday mornings and involve between 5000 to 6300 participants each term.<ref name=IGSSAintro/> Students may choose one Saturday sport per term: [[Image:Kambalastudents.jpg|thumb|150px|Kambala tennis players, [[Circa|c.]] 1890s]] ;Term One *[[Softball]] *[[Tennis]]
;Term Two *[[Basketball]] *[[Soccer]]
;Term Three *[[Netball]] *[[Field hockey|Hockey]]
;Term Four *[[Waterpolo]] *[[Cricket]]<ref name=IGSSAintro/>
==Carnivals== In addition to IGSSA Saturday graded competitions, the association holds six annual carnivals in seven sports: *[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]] *[[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]] and [[Diving]] *Tildesley [[Tennis]] *[[Cross Country Running]] *[[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]] *[[Gymnastics]]
===Rowing=== The IGSSA [[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]] Regatta is typically held in March at the [[Sydney International Regatta Centre]].<ref name=RowingCarnival>{{cite web|url = http://igssa.ahigs.nsw.edu.au/DeskTopDefault.aspx?tabid=303|title =Carnivals - Rowing |accessdate = 2008-03-02|year = 2008|format = doc|work = Carnivals |publisher = Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association}}</ref> The ten schools that offer a rowing programme, and therefore regularly compete in the regatta are: Ascham, Canberra Girls' Grammar School, Loreto Kirribilli, Loreto Normanhurst, MLC School, the Presbyterian Ladies' College, Sydney, Pymble Ladies' College, Queenwood School for Girls, Roseville College, and Tara Anglican School for Girls. ===Swimming and diving=== The IGSSA [[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]] and [[Diving]] carnival has been held annually since 1925. Today it is typically held in March at the [[Sydney Olympic Park]] Aquatic Centre.<ref name=DivingHandbook08>{{cite web |url =http://igssa.ahigs.nsw.edu.au/uploads/Diving%20Handbook.doc |title =Diving Handbook 2008 |accessdate = 2008-03-02 |year = 2008 |format= doc |work = Carnivals |publisher =Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association }}</ref>
In both sports, schools compete in divisions (three for swimming and two for diving) based on their results from the previous year. Both divisions have the same point score and the highest total point score within each division is deemed the Division Champion and presented with a shield.<ref name=DivingHandbook08/><ref name=SwimHandbook08>{{cite web |url =http://igssa.ahigs.nsw.edu.au/uploads/swimming.doc |title =Swimming Handbook 2008 |accessdate = 2008-03-02 |year = 2008 |format= doc |work = Carnivals |publisher =Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association }}</ref> The winning school from each of the first divisions is awarded the carnival champion. ===Athletics=== The IGSSA [[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]] carnival has been held annually since 1923. Today it is typically held in June at Sydney Olympic Park. Competing schools are divided into three divisions based on their results from the previous year. The Division Champions are presented with a shield, with the winning school of the first divisions awarded the carnival champion.<ref name=AthHandbook07>{{cite web |url =http://igssa.ahigs.nsw.edu.au/uploads/athletics2007.doc|title =Athletics Handbook 2007 |accessdate = 2008-03-14 |year = 2008 |format= doc |work = Carnivals - Athletics |publisher =Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association }}</ref>

===Gymnastics=== The IGSSA annual [[Gymnastics]] Carnival was first held in 1969. Today the carnival is typically held in October, at the Sydney Olympic Park Sports Centre in [[Homebush, New South Wales|Homebush]].<ref name=GymCarnival>{{cite web|url = http://igssa.ahigs.nsw.edu.au/DeskTopDefault.aspx?tabid=308|title = Carnivals - Gymnastics |accessdate = 2008-03-02 |year = 2008 |work = Carnivals |publisher = Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association}}</ref> Students may compete in either [[Rhythmic gymnastics|Rhythmic]] (RG) or [[Artistic gymnastics|Artistic]] (WAG) gymnastics, and schools are placed in divisions (two for rhythmic and three for artistic) based on their results from the previous year.<ref name=GymHandbook08>{{cite web |url =http://igssa.ahigs.nsw.edu.au/uploads/GymHandbook%202008.doc |title =Gymnastics Handbook 2008 |accessdate = 2008-03-02 |year = 2008 |format= doc |work = Carnivals |publisher =Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association }}</ref> Through combined WAG and RG results, a Champion school is declared. <!-- Please do not add the crests of Canberra Girls' Grammar, Danebank, Kincoppal, Meriden, or Tara as they are not in the Public Domain (they are fair use images) --> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- bgcolor="#FFCC33" ! ==Tildesley Tennis== [[Image:EvelynTildesley1933.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Evelyn Mary Tildesley (1882–1976), Founder of the Tildesley Shield Competition]] The Tildesley [[Tennis]] Shield competition is IGSSA's longest running carnival. It was first held in 1918, with the now defunct Normanhurst School in [[Ashfield, New South Wales|Ashfield]] declared the champion school, and [[Daphne Akhurst]] (1903–1933) the winner of the singles competition. Akhurst was to become one of the best female tennis players Australia has ever produced. She was a pupil of Normanhurst School,<ref name=Tildesley/> which in 1918 had as its [[Headmistress]], Miss Evelyn Mary Tildesley (1882–1976) from [[Staffordshire]], [[England]].<ref name=ADBTildesley/> Normanhurst School had a very successful tennis program, and by the 1920s had produced two of Australia's most famous female tennis players, with Rosie Payten in addition to Daphne Akhurst. It was Tildesley who donated "a beautiful oak and bronze shield"<ref name=Tildesley/> for a tennis competition which encouraged team spirit amongst Sydney's [[Protestant]] girls' schools.<ref name=Tildesley/>
The Shield was to be presented to the school which showed the best average score in tennis, with each school sending a tenth of its students over the age of twelve. The idea behind this was that each school would be able to give many of their pupils the chance of playing, rather than just a few very talented students, as was the case with the School Girls' Championships held by the New South Wales [[Tennis Australia|Lawn Tennis Association]].<ref name=Tildesley/>
Tildesley was inspired by [[United States|American]] Tennis Tournaments in determining how her competition would be scored. In such tournaments, a percentage of games won against games played is taken. This system of scoring has often been criticised over the years, particularly by the larger schools, and to this day it remains highly unusual for a large school to win the Tildesley Shield. It is however apparent that the reasoning that prompted Tildesley was that of encouraging more participation in tennis amongst the 12 Protestant schools operating in 1918, and to have a scoring system which rewarded the school with the best average.<ref name=Tildesley/> [[Image:Pymbletennis1917.jpg|thumb|left|220px|Pymble tennis team, 1917]] Until 1922, the competition was managed by the Girls Secondary Schools Lawn Tennis Association, and after this time, the Girls Secondary Schools Sports Union (now IGSSA). From 1922 until 1944, the Tildesley Shield was held, where possible, on three consecutive Saturdays in October at [[White City Stadium (Sydney)|White City Stadium]]. In 1918 it was held at the [[Double Bay, New South Wales|Double Bay]] Courts, as White City was then a fun parlour which was taken over for [[Tennis court#Grass courts|grass courts]] circa 1920–21. Matches were the best of eight games, with entries based on a 1:15 ratio for girls 12 years and over on 1 October, with a minimum of 12 (6 [[Types of tennis match|singles]], 3 [[Types of tennis match|doubles]]) and a maximum of 32 (16 singles, 8 doubles).<ref name=Tildesley/>
From 1944 to 1946, the numbers were modified to 1:25, with a minimum of eight (4 singles, 2 doubles) and a maximum of 20 (10 singles, 5 doubles). In 1947 it reverted to the original scheme until 1971 when the Entry Scheme was redrafted. In 1980, it was again redrafted to a system of a 1:22 ratio, by Miss Patti Dyson, then Headmistress of [[Presbyterian Ladies' College, Sydney|PLC Sydney]]. All matches are now one set only, first to 9 games, no advantage. A [[Tennis score#Scoring a tiebreak game|tie-breaker]] is used at 7–all in quarter finals, semi-finals and finals only. Games Won, Games Lost, Games Played in all singles and doubles games are totalled for each school, with the final percentage for each school being the number of games won over the number of games played.<ref name=Tildesley/>
The continuous attempts to redraft the conditions of the Shield are largely due to the prestigious place the competition holds in Independent Girls' School Tennis. However, it has remained essential that the conditions stay true to the principles of the donor. If Miss Tildesley had wished the Shield to be reserved for the champions, which would have led to her school winning more often, then the conditions of play would have been much different. However, Tildesley, along with her sister Beatrice and Mr Henry Marsh, who had developed the concept with her, insisted that the school with the best average of games won the Shield.<ref name=Tildesley/> As Marsh explained in his article in the Normanhurst Jubilee Magazine: {{cquote2|It is the most coveted trophy in school tennis because it teaches the girls to play for their school rather than for themselves, its special value lying in the fact that at least 12 girls, with a maximum of 32, according to the number of pupils over 12 years of age, compete for the trophy, thereby giving a number of the younger girls an opportunity of representing their School which they would not otherwise get until much later.<ref name=Tildesley/>}}
In 1998, Mr Peter Spender donated a trophy for the Most Improved Tildesley Shield Tournament School, in memory of his wife Diane Greaves, an ex–[[SCEGGS Darlinghurst]] student. Any school who improves their position from the previous year automatically becomes eligible to win the Spender trophy, and for each place gained points are awarded. Points are then accumulated according to the number of places a school improves.<ref name=Tildesley08/>
Today the Tildesley Shield Competition is open to all IGSSA schools, with 24 of them typically choosing to compete, and takes place at the [[Thornleigh, New South Wales|Thornleigh]] Tennis Centre in [[Eastwood, New South Wales|Eastwood]] over three consecutive days, usually in April. Entry is accepted according to a ratio of 1:33 secondary enrolments, which may change slightly each year due to changes in enrolment numbers.<ref name=Tildesley08>{{cite web|url= http://igssa.ahigs.nsw.edu.au/uploads/Tildesley%20Rules%20&%20Guidelines.doc|title= Annual Tildesley Shield Tennis Tournament 2008 |accessdate= 2008-03-02|year= 2008|format= doc|work= Tildesley|publisher= Independent Girls' Schools Sporting Association}}</ref>
